
A good first step is to usually just toss images into `CyberChef` or 
[Aperi'solve](https://aperisolve.fr/ffdf85ef72295c18a94f75384f972c44) (online Zsteg, basically).

Here, we find: 

```
meta Raw64 .. text: ""
meta Description .. text: "Do you believe in magic?"
```

Take the base64 looking string and toss it into [CyberChef](https://gchq.github.io/CyberChef/#recipe=From_Base64('A-Za-z0-9%2B/%3D',true)To_Hexdump(16,false,false,false)&).

If you scroll around and view the data a little, you can find some odd things:

There are some repeated chunks including the symbol for Word's line ending (called "pilcrow?") (`0xff`)
from about row `0x00000030` to row `0x00000090`.

Then, we see some rows of mutations of the bytestring `ID3II*\0` from `0x000000b0` to `00000100`,
and then _again_ in the last row, `0x00000320`.

The cycle length of BOTH repeating patterns is `7`. Adjusting CyberChef's hexdump width gives us a 
better view of the data.

Now, if you can read transistor diagrams, you would know for a fact the next step is `xor`.
Even if you can't, you hopefully know enough about cyptography to know that the other 
logical operations aren't invertible, so `xor`ing data with a key is the only viable way to encrypt
a message.

Setting the width to `7`, we can confirm the key `b6 b6 d5 ff b6 bb cc` appears as a row repeatedly.<br>
[Try `xor`ing the data](https://gchq.github.io/CyberChef/#recipe=From_Base64('A-Za-z0-9%2B/%3D',true)XOR(%7B'option':'Hex','string':'b6%20b6%20d5%20ff%20b6%20bb%20cc'%7D,'Standard',false)To_Hexdump(7,false,false,false)&)
with this key.

What we find is... nothing. This is where I personally gave up with this avenue and started looking
into doing a frequency analysis to extract other information from the data.

What I should have done is just try a couple more things, like 
[`xor`ing with the _negation_ of the key](https://gchq.github.io/CyberChef/#recipe=From_Base64('A-Za-z0-9%2B/%3D',true)XOR(%7B'option':'Hex','string':'b6%20b6%20d5%20ff%20b6%20bb%20cc'%7D,'Standard',false)XOR(%7B'option':'Hex','string':'FF'%7D,'Standard',false)To_Hexdump(7,false,false,false)&).

Now, CyberChef's magic takes us the rest of the way, rendering the JPG containing the flag `ictf{m4gic_byt3s_F7W!}`.
